question_text: What was the purpose behind organizing the 'Student Workshop Hub' at Bright Future Secondary School? Choose all the correct answers.

options.A: To showcase students' creative solutions to school and neighborhood problems
options.B: To transform the school campus into a creative hotspot for community-minded projects
options.C: To encourage students to study traditional academic subjects
options.D: To help students take pride in contributing to something bigger than themselves
options.E: To celebrate the school's tenth anniversary

related_paragraphs.text: Last month, a bustling workshop atmosphere brought together students, parents, and teachers at Bright Future Secondary School. Located in Ontario, Canada, the school hosted its first-ever "Student Workshop Hub," a week-long event where students showcased creative solutions to problems affecting their school and neighborhood.

The event was organized by Emma and Paul Gibson, long-time educators who had envisioned turning the campus into a creative hotspot for community-minded projects. When they opened Bright Future Secondary School ten years ago, their dream was to create a space where students could not only study but also explore skills spanning technology, design, and even small-scale manufacturing. Their vision came to life with this event.

The idea for the Student Workshop Hub came to Emma when she noticed how much her own children enjoyed school activities that required them to solve real-world problems. From recycling initiatives to building birdhouses for local parks, students seemed to take pride in being part of something bigger than themselves. Emma became determined to bring a similar experience to Bright Future Secondary School.

question_text: Which of the following is closest in meaning to ‘pride’ in paragraph 6?

related_paragraphs.text: The idea for the Student Workshop Hub came to Emma when she noticed how much her own children enjoyed school activities that required them to solve real-world problems. Emma became determined to bring a similar experience to Bright Future Secondary School.

related_paragraphs.text: The idea for the Student Workshop Hub came to Emma when she noticed how much her own children enjoyed school activities that required them to solve real-world problems. From recycling initiatives to building birdhouses for local parks, students seemed to take pride in being part of something bigger than themselves. Emma became determined to bring a similar experience to Bright Future Secondary School.

Paul also saw a unique opportunity to combine educational goals with environmental awareness: 'Projects like these teach students how interconnected the world is. Whether they're improving green spaces in our city or creating art installations with recycled materials, kids start to see how their actions ripple outward.'

The campaign prompted widespread enthusiasm. Parents offered to contribute materials, school administrators provided funding, and teachers incorporated elements of the workshop into their lessons. Among the highlights of the week were workshops where students learned woodworking, coding, and sustainable gardening techniques.

question_text: What does Nia believe projects like hers teach, as described in paragraph 11?

related_paragraphs.text: Beyond environmental work, twelve-year-old Nia worked on a social project aimed at helping underprivileged children access educational supplies. 'We collected unused items like pencils, notebooks, and rulers and distributed them to local families in need,' Nia explained. She believes projects like hers teach empathy and resourcefulness: 'A small gesture can make a big difference.'

question_text: Based on the information in the text, match each statement to the person or group it describes. One statement is NOT used. Write NG (not given) if the statement is not mentioned in the text.

statements.text: They were inspired by the students’ dedication and helped organize their work.
They supported the students in budgeting and marketing their ideas.
They aim to focus on mental health awareness projects in the next year.
They believe the skills students gain here will help them in a rapidly changing world.
They organized a global education initiative connecting students from different countries.

related_paragraphs.text: Meanwhile, Phyllis Watson, a retired local librarian who volunteered during the hub, was inspired by how far-reaching the students' efforts had been. 'The dedication these kids show is nothing short of incredible. Seeing them put their thoughts into tangible projects is very uplifting,' said Phyllis as she helped organize folders showcasing students' work.

As Emma and Paul reflected on the hub's success, they pointed to the parents' involvement as a key factor in bringing their vision to life. Many parents not only supported the event financially but also mentored students in areas like budgeting, marketing their ideas, and logistics.

The Student Workshop Hub, according to Emma, is just the first of many initiatives planned for Bright Future Secondary School. 'This is the beginning. Next year, we aim to tackle projects focused on mental health awareness, local history preservation, and even global initiatives connecting students from different countries,' she said.

Paul shared similar optimism: 'The skills our students are gaining through these projects — teamwork, innovation, and resilience — will stick with them for life. We're giving them the toolkit to adapt and thrive in a rapidly changing world.'

question_text: Put the events mentioned below in the correct order. Write (1-5) in the boxes provided.

statements.text: Lara and her classmates created an outdoor terrace project.
The Student Workshop Hub event was hosted at Bright Future Secondary School.
Ethan developed a system to track classroom energy usage.
Nia started a social project to help underprivileged children access educational supplies.
Students presented their completed projects to the community during an open house event.

related_paragraphs.text: Last month, a bustling workshop atmosphere brought together students, parents, and teachers at Bright Future Secondary School. Located in Ontario, Canada, the school hosted its first-ever 'Student Workshop Hub,' a week-long event where students showcased creative solutions to problems affecting their school and neighborhood.

Fifteen-year-old Lara and her classmates formed a group called 'Eco School Advocates' and worked tirelessly on an outdoor terrace project. 'We wanted to create a shared space in our school where people could relax and connect with nature,' Lara explained. Her group planted native grass species, installed seating made from re-purposed wood, and produced a mural illustrating how ecosystems thrive when people work harmoniously with nature.

Thirteen-year-old Ethan was equally dedicated, putting his energy into developing an automated system for tracking classroom energy usage. 'I realized that lights were often left on when no one was around,' Ethan said. 'So I built code that monitors energy consumption and sends alerts when electricity is being wasted.' The technology drew interest from both teachers and school administrators.

Beyond environmental work, twelve-year-old Nia worked on a social project aimed at helping underprivileged children access educational supplies. 'We collected unused items like pencils, notebooks, and rulers and distributed them to local families in need,' Nia explained. She believes projects like hers teach empathy and resourcefulness: 'A small gesture can make a big difference.'

At the end of the week, students proudly presented their completed projects during an open house event attended by nearly 700 community members. Their ingenuity was celebrated, and many visitors left inspired by the potential for schools to cultivate meaningful change. Bright Future Secondary School is already planning the next session of the hub, which promises more opportunities for students to innovate and grow.

As Emma and Paul reflected on the hub's success, they pointed to the parents' involvement as a key factor in bringing their vision to life. Many parents not only supported the event financially but also mentored students in areas like budgeting, marketing their ideas, and logistics.

related_paragraphs.text: Education is evolving, and schools around the world are embracing innovative approaches to learning. From community outreach to hands-on creative projects, students are being challenged to think critically and develop real-world skills. At the heart of this transformation are initiatives designed to make learning interactive, engaging, and impactful.

Through these kinds of programs, schools worldwide are empowering students to turn ideas into action and showing them how to make a meaningful impact, both inside and outside the classroom. As education continues to evolve, initiatives like the Student Workshop Hub will undoubtedly inspire generations of learners to shape a brighter, more connected future.

During the workshop, students applied their skills to create practical solutions to real-world ___ affecting their school and local ___ . Among the many student projects, Lara and her classmates developed an outdoor terrace with seating created from ___ wood. Ethan built an automated system to track classroom energy ___ and provided alerts to address instances of ___ electricity usage. The Arts and Drama Club put on performances exploring cultural ___ , such as folklore, family dynamics, and societal change. related_paragraphs.text: Last month, a bustling workshop atmosphere brought together students, parents, and teachers at Bright Future Secondary School. Located in Ontario, Canada, the school hosted its first-ever "Student Workshop Hub," a week-long event where students showcased creative solutions to problems affecting their school and neighborhood.

The event was organized by Emma and Paul Gibson, long-time educators who had envisioned turning the campus into a creative hotspot for community-minded projects. When they opened Bright Future Secondary School ten years ago, their dream was to create a space where students could not only study but also explore skills spanning technology, design, and even small-scale manufacturing. Their vision came to life with this event.

Fifteen-year-old Lara and her classmates formed a group called "Eco School Advocates" and worked tirelessly on an outdoor terrace project. "We wanted to create a shared space in our school where people could relax and connect with nature," Lara explained. Her group planted native grass species, installed seating made from re-purposed wood, and produced a mural illustrating how ecosystems thrive when people work harmoniously with nature.

Thirteen-year-old Ethan was equally dedicated, putting his energy into developing an automated system for tracking classroom energy usage. "I realized that lights were often left on when no one was around," Ethan said. "So I built code that monitors energy consumption and sends alerts when electricity is being wasted." The technology drew interest from both teachers and school administrators.

Other standout moments included performances conducted by the Arts and Drama Club highlighting cultural diversity, traditional folklore, and modern interpretations of societal changes. "Art has the ability to foster understanding," said Alan, a sixteen-year-old aspiring theater director. His group performed a play that explored shifting family dynamics in modern society, which resonated with many attendees.

As Emma and Paul reflected on the hub's success, they pointed to the parents' involvement as a key factor in bringing their vision to life. Many parents not only supported the event financially but also mentored students in areas like budgeting, marketing their ideas, and logistics.

The Student Workshop Hub, according to Emma, is just the first of many initiatives planned for Bright Future Secondary School. "This is the beginning. Next year, we aim to tackle projects focused on mental health awareness, local history preservation, and even global initiatives connecting students from different countries," she said.

related_paragraphs.text: In an era where schools are increasingly embracing digital tools and online platforms, Harmony Learning Centre chooses a different path. This institution prioritises personal connection, traditional learning methods, and hands-on activities to foster deeper understanding among students.

Group projects, team games, and face-to-face discussions have replaced solitary computer sessions. Students here share ideas, solve puzzles, and engage in collaborative learning exercises, all while leaving their phones behind.

question_text: Decide whether the following statements are True, False, or Not Given based on paragraphs 7-8.

statements.text: Emma believes interpersonal skills are crucial for modern collaborative learning.
Digital connectivity is the primary focus of Harmony School’s interactive approach.
Harmony School students analyze scientific data during Community Brainstorm Sessions.
Joshua observes that students learn a lot through interaction during group discussions.

related_paragraphs.text: Emma, a former education specialist, is enthusiastic about introducing all her students to collaborative learning models. “We live in times where everyone is connected digitally, but interpersonal skills are often lacking. Learning should involve conversations and understanding diverse perspectives, not isolated scrolling through screens.”

For example, every Wednesday afternoon features what Harmony calls “Community Brainstorm Sessions.” Students present ideas or ask questions related to science, literature, or history, and, through group discussions, reach conclusions collaboratively. “It's amazing to see how much they absorb from each other just by interacting,” Joshua adds.

This aligns with Harmony's commitment to meaningful learning experiences,” Hugh explains proudly.

related_paragraphs.text: Students come from diverse backgrounds to join Harmony but all find themselves immersed in this unique and close-knit culture. Anna Fong, a student from Year 9, shares: “At first, I was shy about participating in group activities. But these initiatives helped me open up, and now I love working with my classmates. My favourite event is when we work together in science lab experiments; it's exciting to learn in a group!”

My favourite event is when we work together in science lab experiments; it's exciting to learn in a group!”

question_text: Based on information provided in paragraphs 11-15, what do the following people say about engaging in hands-on activities or traditional learning methods?

related_paragraphs.section: The Benefits of Engaging Hands-on Activities
related_paragraphs.text: Hugh Lee, co-teacher for Skill Unity, believes these interactive approaches make children emotionally resilient. “When kids play and collaborate actively, they naturally learn teamwork without being explicitly told. This aligns with Harmony's commitment to meaningful learning experiences,” Hugh explains proudly.

Games like Chinese Chess, Sudoku boards, and geometric puzzles are widely popular here. Emma believes such games not only provide mental discipline but also offer insights into social dynamics and reasoning techniques. “Take Chinese Chess as an example. It's fantastic for learning strategy and balance while also engaging students with parts of cultural heritage,” Emma explains.

Among Harmony's cohort, Year 8 student Kevin Lam has developed a knack for strategic planning thanks to playing board games during breaks. After practising such games enthusiastically, Kevin says it's easier to make quick revisions to his math projects or address unanticipated challenges during discussions. “The problem-solving here makes me sharper in nearly every school subject,” he admits.

question_text: Use information given in paragraphs 14-19 and match each person with the correct speech.

statements.text: Playing board games makes me sharper in my school subjects.
Face-to-face learning strengthens social skills, which I always wanted for my child.
Families come together for creative ideas, making learning enjoyable for everyone involved.
Chess strategies explained during games help tie generations together.
Re-enacting historical moments is both fun and educational.

related_paragraphs.text: Among Harmony's cohort, Year 8 student Kevin Lam has developed a knack for strategic planning thanks to playing board games during breaks. After practising such games enthusiastically, Kevin says it's easier to make quick revisions to his math projects or address unanticipated challenges during discussions. “The problem-solving here makes me sharper in nearly every school subject,” he admits.

Parents particularly rave about Harmony's ability to engage students with such activities. “The focus on face-to-face learning that strengthens social skills is something I always wanted for my child,” says Mrs Wong, mother of ten-year-old Margaret. “This school feels refreshing when many others only push online video lessons.”

Joshua notices the joy in creating simple items such as manually powered flashlights or water-saving devices: “When families come together for such ideas, the excitement is palpable. Learning becomes enjoyable for everyone involved.”

“We participated in Family Chess Night last term,” shares Mr Ho, who regularly attends Harmony's weekend co-learning sessions with his son Noah. “It wasn't just about winning the match; it's about explaining chess strategies to younger players. These mindful games help tie generations together with smoother communication too.”

Another popular session hosted regularly is “Historic Role Playing.” Children gather with guardians or leisure-time educators to re-enact key moments from history, adding creative interpretations where needed. It's both fun and educational and serves Harmony's broader mission to blend diverse approaches to learning.

question_text: Complete the following summary about Harmony Learning Centre. Use ONE word to fill in each blank. (Hyphenated words count as one word.)
text_for_fill: The Harmony Learning Centre focuses on traditional and ___ ways of learning, prioritising hands-on activities and ___ interactions over digital ones. Group projects and teamwork-based games are central in helping students ___ with their classmates effectively. In contrast to solitary computer sessions, Harmony's collaborative approach includes ___ activities and discussions. Classrooms showcase colourful charts, puzzles, and ___ maps created by students. Outdoor trips and creative workshops are organised where even elderly family members participate through ___ circles. Emma, a former education specialist, emphasises improving ___ skills, as over-reliance on screens limits interpersonal connections. With events like “Community ___ Sessions” every Wednesday afternoon, students actively engage in presenting ideas and ___ solutions as a group. Another popular feature is the “Skill Unity” segment every Saturday, in which students ___ prototypes, solve riddles, or act out historical events. Activities like these help students become emotionally resilient while teaching critical thinking. For Year 9 student Anna Fong, group science lab experiments have aided her in becoming more ___ and open. Hugh Lee, a ___ for Skill Unity, highlights that playing and collaborating naturally fosters teamwork. Harmony also believes in reviving classic games and logical challenges to ___ students' minds and promote nostalgia in older generations. Emma concludes that collaborative learning models shape students ___ for their academic and social development. Harmony aspires to help children grow into emotionally ___ individuals able to appreciate deeper, slow-paced and ___ experiences.

related_paragraphs.text: In an era where schools are increasingly embracing digital tools and online platforms, Harmony Learning Centre chooses a different path. This institution prioritises personal connection, traditional learning methods, and hands-on activities to foster deeper understanding among students.

Group projects, team games, and face-to-face discussions have replaced solitary computer sessions. Students here share ideas, solve puzzles, and engage in collaborative learning exercises, all while leaving their phones behind.

Classrooms are designed similar to inclusive sitting areas found in libraries, with round tables and interactive smart boards used sparingly. The corridors display walls of puzzles, mind maps, and colourful charts created by students. Even the playground is thoughtfully arranged, offering games that promote teamwork and communication.

The learning centre also organises activities such as outdoor trips, creative workshops, and debates. Parents and even grandparents are often invited to host story circles, imparting wisdom from their generations while bonding with the younger crowd.

For example, every Wednesday afternoon features what Harmony calls “Community Brainstorm Sessions.” Students present ideas or ask questions related to science, literature, or history, and, through group discussions, reach conclusions collaboratively. “It's amazing to see how much they absorb from each other just by interacting,” Joshua adds.

related_paragraphs.section: The Benefits of Engaging Hands-on Activities
related_paragraphs.text: One of Harmony Learning Centre's biggest attractions is its “Skill Unity” segment, conducted every Saturday. For two hours, students engage in fun group exercises such as making miniature prototypes of bridges, solving riddles, or role-playing historical events. It allows them to learn teamwork, critical thinking, and creativity.

related_paragraphs.section: The Benefits of Engaging Hands-on Activities
related_paragraphs.text: Hugh Lee, co-teacher for Skill Unity, believes these interactive approaches make children emotionally resilient. “When kids play and collaborate actively, they naturally learn teamwork without being explicitly told. This aligns with Harmony's commitment to meaningful learning experiences,” Hugh explains proudly.

Harmony incorporates classic games and logical challenges into their curriculum, reviving methods that many education systems have abandoned. This effort helps sharpen the minds of students while stimulating a sense of nostalgia for older generations.

Emma remarks: “When kids interact naturally or share creative input each day working together collaboratively, students learn both academic concepts related through consistent dynamic relationships evolving forward effectively shaping them socially over years ahead ultimately.”

question_text: Why does Harmony Learning Centre incorporate traditional games like Chinese Chess? Give one reason from the text to support your answer.
answer: they offer insights into social dynamics/reasoning techniques
they engage students with cultural heritage

related_paragraphs.text: Games like Chinese Chess, Sudoku boards, and geometric puzzles are widely popular here. Emma believes such games not only provide mental discipline but also offer insights into social dynamics and reasoning techniques. “Take Chinese Chess as an example. It's fantastic for learning strategy and balance while also engaging students with parts of cultural heritage,” Emma explains.

question_text: Does Harmony Learning Centre focus more on traditional or digital learning methods? Give one reason to support each point of view from the provided paragraphs.

answer: the institution prioritises personal connection, hands-on activities and face-to-face learning to foster understanding
it replaces solitary computer sessions with group projects, team games, and discussions
Harmony chooses a different path, but some may argue digital tools and online platforms offer more convenience/efficiency
digital learning methods can provide access to a wider range of resources for students

related_paragraphs.text: In an era where schools are increasingly embracing digital tools and online platforms, Harmony Learning Centre chooses a different path. This institution prioritises personal connection, traditional learning methods, and hands-on activities to foster deeper understanding among students.

Group projects, team games, and face-to-face discussions have replaced solitary computer sessions. Students here share ideas, solve puzzles, and engage in collaborative learning exercises, all while leaving their phones behind.
